speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear argument next this morning in Case 10-5258, McNeill v. United States. Mr. Gordon.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, I -- I have just one problem, which is under your theory, I understand it, if a State increases a penalty, makes what would have been a penalty for a misdemeanor now a felony, then that defendant is a career criminal, by your logic.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So the person who thought that at the time they committed the crime they were committing a low-level crime is now a felon; is that your theory of the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What -- what -- what logic do you think there is in that, why Congress would want to punish someone now for -- for criminal activity that they thought was lesser, and the State thought was lesser, at an earlier time, less reprehensible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Gordon, the State does regard it -- it does -- prescribe 10 years for this defendant because it's made a -- made the change not retroactive.  So a maximum of 10 years is prescribed for Mr. McNeill, and all others who committed the offense prior to the change in law.  So it is -- it is the State's current position that for this offense the maximum is 10 years.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose -- what would happen in this situation?  A defendant is convicted under a State statute that says that anybody who sells between 1 ounces -- 1 ounce and 5 ounces of a particular controlled substance is guilty of a felony and may be punished by imprisonment for a certain amount of time. And then the State repeals that provision altogether and enacts a new provision that says anybody who sells between 1 ounces -- 1 ounce and 8 ounces is punishable by a certain penalty.  And now the question comes up what -- what penalty does the court look at with respect to the earlier offense that no longer exists for which the defendant was convicted?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mis --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Gordon, is this -- is this essentially an academic question?  Because this district judge said that he would impose the same sentence as a variant even if he couldn't do it under the guidelines, even if it were an incorrect calculation.  He said:  This criminal record is violent and astonishing; essentially, I'm going to throw the book at him, and I'm going to do it through a variant if that's no -- if there's no other way. So isn't that -- I mean, isn't this an -- an exercise, essentially an academic exercise, if -- if your -- your client would end up in the same place?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Gordon, there are other provisions in ACCA which seem to use the present tense in circumstances where it doesn't seem as though the statute truly means the present tense.  So, a violent felony is one that "has as an element the use of physical force, is burglary, arson, or extortion, involves use of explosives;" and so on and so forth. But we would not look as to -- in interpreting that provision to the present day, would we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why is -- why is -- why is the present tense inadequate for the -- for the government's position in this case?  Once it is conceded that the North Carolina law is not retroactive, the law reducing the number of years, it is the case that what is the maximum term of imprisonment for the offense that he committed -- how many years ago was it, whatever --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What is the maximum punishment for that offense which occurred at that time is the longer period.  Why is -- I don't see why your argument requires us to ask what would be the term if he had committed the offense at a later date.  The maximum term for his offense when he committed it is those years because the State did not retroactively reduce his sentence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's not just for the defendant; it's for anybody who committed it prior to the -- prior to the amendment of the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Anybody that committed it then, the -- the -- it is an offense "involving manufacturing, distributing, or possessing with intent to manufacture or distribute a controlled...for which a maximum term of imprisonment of 10 years or more is prescribed by law."  It is prescribed by law for any of those offenses that occurred between whenever that old statute was enacted and whenever this statute was enacted.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if the State --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if the State change is to abolish the offense altogether?  Do we -- do we not have any predicate offense for the defendant who committed the crime prior to the abolition of the State offense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me.  That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's correct?  You're happy with that?  The person committed a felony when it was a felony, and the State later no longer makes it a felony, and it isn't counted for purposes of the Armed Career Criminal Act?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but it strikes me that there's really no change in the State view of how serious it is.  It was just an overall change in how they're going to look at sentencing.  Under the prior regime, you're sentenced to a particular term, but in fact you serve a lot less.  With the new treatment in sentencing, you're sentenced to what is a much -- a smaller term, but you in fact are going to serve the whole thing.  At the end of the day, there's no real change in how they view the seriousness of the offense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Are we looking at it because we want the States to determine the Federal sentence or are we looking at it because we evaluate the evil of the particular defendant on the basis of how -- how much of a crime he was willing to commit? And so long as it was a serious felony when he committed it, this is a bad actor.  I don't care if the State changes its view.  At the time, he was willing to commit a felony that put him in jail for 10 years, and that's what we're looking to, it seems to me, how bad an apple is this fellow that -- that we're talking about putting away?  And that doesn't change simply because the State decides in the future that that same act will not be a felony.  Well, people who perform that act in the future aren't so bad; they're just -- you know, just normal not-so-good people -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- but they're not the kind of a person who's willing to -- to commit a felony that, you know, puts them away for 10 years. It seems to me that that's what the Federal law is looking to.  We're not giving over to the States the decision of -- of how long we should incarcerate somebody in a Federal prison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I agree, it does refer to the seriousness of the offense.  But it refers to the seriousness of the offense at the time the offense was committed in order to determine how bad a fellow this is, not -- not because we want the States to determine how long we're going to keep Federal prisoners in prison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's the issue, though, really.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you'll -- you'll put away for a long time somebody who really wasn't that bad a guy.  He committed a misdemeanor, and when the State later makes it a felony, you -- he suddenly comes under ACCA.  And I -- I can't believe that that's -- that's what -- what Congress had in mind just because the State now thinks that it's more serious.  Who cares what the State thinks?  We -- we want to know how bad an actor this particular defendant is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm not sure what you're urging now.  Are -- are you modifying or retracting the answer you gave to Justice Sotomayor, that is, the case where the maximum was 5 years, but then at the time of the Federal offense the State has changed it so it's 10 years? I -- I think you answered her question that it would work the same way, that what mattered is how the State currently ranks the offense, not the offender. But now you seem to be saying there might be a different answer when the State increases rather than decreases the penalty.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In -- in the hypothetical where the penalty is increased, would there be an ex post facto problem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry, how do you see that?  I thought the government had two alternative positions, the first being that you look at the time -- at the time of the offense, at the conviction or, alternatively, it was arguing the way to take the position of the court below.  But if you're going to use the present tense then you look retroactively to see -- then you look to see whether the State would retroactively apply the new sentence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You understood their brief differently?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sure they'll tell you. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Gordon. Mr. Gannon.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could I -- just to clarify your point.  If there's been a modification of law that would have entitled him to a retroactive change in his sentence, although I'm not quite sure how that works, because if there's a modification, I thought it would only apply to a defendant who had committed the crime at that earlier time but was convicted at the present time.  This defendant wouldn't have his sentence modified.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, that's my question.  Is your footnote related to that kind of individual only or are you saying -- or are you accepting your adversary's argument that the circuit below got it right?  You look at the is as to what the sentence would be today --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- if this person had committed the crime?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm just trying to clarify whether you mean that the -- the modification had to have occurred, meaning that he was convicted, he got 10 years, and somewhere for some State reason, that actual final judgment was amended to include 5.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Are or are you talking about --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- accepting his argument that if he could apply for a change now --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is this the first time you're advancing the argument, the first part of your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It doesn't appear as you did -- if you did it below; am I correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if the legislature decreases the penalty because it really has taken a different -- a new look at the nature of the offense and has come to the conclusion that this really is not nearly as serious as we -- as we previously thought?  So why should the prior judgment about the severity of the offense be taken into account under ACCA?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But what if --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if they had repudiated their prior normative judgment?  And -- and even -- what if they even had made it -- made the new sentence retroactive, but a particular defendant was no longer in prison, so wasn't on parole, so there was nothing -- there was no way that this could have any effect on that person?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not sure it's so hard. I -- I could find my way clear to saying that if it has been retroactively made a -- a -- a lesser offense, that that would qualify under -- under the statute.  I don't know why you insist that his actual conviction be -- be altered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can you tell us whether changes in State sentences -- do the States routinely address retroactivity?  Or do they leave it to their general common law?  Or do you have any idea of what --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Gannon. Mr. Gordon, you have 6 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
